awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CEDAR: Characterization of Ionospheric-Thermospheric Long-lasting SED (Storm Enhanced Density) Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration: The goal of the research is to understand the initiation and development of a phenomenon called mid-latitude long-lasting storm enhanced density (LLSED). LLSEDs are regions of enhanced electron density at low latitudes that emanate from midlatitude SED plumes. The term "plume" refers to structures in the Earth's magnetosphere and ionosphere that couple these two systems and redistribute plasma among them. LLSEDs last over 6 hours, outliving the SED plumes that spawn them, and can potentially adversely impact communication and navigation systems. However, there remains no consensus on their causes. The work skillfully fuses ground- and space-based data with numerical modeling tools to examine ionospheric disturbances that are of some concern for the aviation and telecommunication industries. The grant will support an early career minority scientist, and contribute to Catholic U's REU program.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Even now, many aspects of ionospheric storms remain unresolved. In particular, the characteristics and driving mechanisms of long-lasting Storm Enhanced Density (LLSED) events are largely still a subject of intense debate. The overarching goal of the proposed research is to comprehensively examine the characteristics and driving processes that lead to the generation and development of mid-latitude LLSED.

 

This 3-year data analysis and numerical modeling effort was focused on addressing several intriguing questions concerning the characteristics and physical processes associated with mid-latitude LLSED. The proposed study required an integration of several different resources to successfully address the goals. The data sets used were carefully selected to positively identify LLSED events and the physical processes that contribute to their formation, specifically, composition, electric fields, and winds. Complementing these data sets are various models that provide a framework for analysis and understanding of LLSED initiation and evolution.

 

A total of 58 LLSED events were identified and confirmed out of 665 events examined in the North American sector for the period from 2000 to 2018. The American sector was picked because: (i) SED events are more commonly observed in the American sector (which is believed to be related to the geomagnetic field orientation); (ii) access to TEC data from the American sector is earlier than other sectors around the globe. We found that out of the 665 geomagnetic storms between the years 2000 to 2018, only 8% of the storms were associated with LLSED development. The statistical study also shows that LLSED events have a strong solar cycle, local time, and longitude dependence. Additionally, the statistical analysis reveals that majority (> 40%) of the LLSED events were associated with minor to moderate geomagnetic storm conditions, i.e., Dst > -100 nT. We also found that unlike the American equatorial latitudes, there was no nighttime commencement of LLSED at mid-latitudes.

 

To investigate the relationship between enhanced electron densities and convection electric fields for the 56 events, we ran high latitude assimilations using the AMIE algorithm to generate high latitude convection patterns. These convection patterns were used to drive global first-principles ionosphere-thermosphere models (TIEGCM or TIMEGCM) for 52 out of 58 events, to investigate whether the models recreated the observed SED features. The assimilative ionospheric electron density model (IDA4D) was run at ASTRA for one event to study the ionospheric structure in more detail than provided by the first-principles models alone. To validate the models and to provide insight into the mechanisms at work during LLSED events, we collected measurements of thermospheric neutral winds from the Millstone Hill Fabry-Perot interferometer (FPI) for various events. ASTRA also collected data on the thermospheric composition during these events as provided by the TIMED-GUVI and DMSP-SSUSI UV instruments for various events. We found that a combination of driving processes is likely active at different stages of geomagnetic storms and substorms, including enhanced high latitude convection and particle injection, prompt penetration electric fields, disturbance dynamo effects, travelling ionospheric disturbances, neutral winds, and composition.

 

The project has resulted in two published papers (with one under review and two others in preparation), and over 8 conference presentations.

 

Broader Impacts: The project has contributed to NSF STEM goals through mentoring and collaborations. During the project, the PI mentored several undergraduate students from the City University of New York (CUNNY) Queens Borough Community College and two undergraduate students from University of Maryland. The students worked on the project performing data analysis and identification of LLSED events and were lead authors on scientific presentations at important scientific conferences. One of the students from University of Maryland was recently accepted into an MA Astronomy program at Wesleyan University. We have also worked with CUNNY, a Minority Serving Institution (MSI), to develop innovations in curriculum and experiential learning opportunities. Various international collaborations have been seeded by the project, including a STEM initiative in Zambia, collaborations with research scientists in France and South Africa, and supporting an ionospheric scientist in Nigeria put together a Research Plan to develop a robust ionospheric research program in Nigeria.
